_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary:





ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION POLICIES



Sun-Maid Ripperdan - Facility has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the sulfur dioxide process.  Sun-Maid Ripperdan - Facility's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substance.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

Sun-Maid Ripperdan - Facility is located at 27400 Avenue 6, Madera, California.  The regulated substance managed at the facility is sulfur dioxide.  At most, nine (9) one-ton cylinders are kept on-site for a total of 18,000 pounds (lbs.).  



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

As part of the implementation of this CalARP Program, key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by Sun-Maid Ripperdan - Facility to manage process safety issues associated with the use of sulfur dioxide.  Furthermore, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.

The facility is limited to a maximum intended inventory of sulfur dioxide of nine (9) one-ton cylinders (2,000 lbs. each) are kept on-site for a total of 18,000 lbs.  The regulated substance is over the 500-lb. state threshold for CalARP Program.  As a result, the sulfur dioxide covered process is subject to CalARP Program 3.



HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY/OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS



Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary

Scenario Description: One worst-case analysis has been defined and modeled for the sulfur dioxide process.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located in the 2020 CalARP/RMP/PSM Program 3 - Five Year Update Binder.



Alternative Release Scenario Results Summary

Scenario Description: An alternative release scenario was modeled.  The results can

be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located in the 2020 CalARP/RMP/PSM Program 3 - Five Year Update Binder.



Risk Considerations

Although the storage and use of sulfur dioxide has inherent potential risks, and worst-case release scenarios can potentially reach the community; Sun-Maid Ripperdan - Facility has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst case type of event non-credible.  In addition to the safety practices of the company and plant personnel to make this worst-case event non-credible, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such event.

In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with a sulfur dioxide release:

?There are process valves to permit isolation of any leaks in place.

?The system undergoes scheduled maintenance to reduce the likelihood of catastrophic failures.

?Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) is used by facility personnel, as necessary

?Well-designed Relief System and Relief Valves 

?Gas Detection Systems and Alarms

?Safety Showers/Eyewash Stations



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

For any accidental release meeting the five-year accident history reporting criteria of 19 CCR ?2750.9, the owner or operator shall submit the data required under ?2745.5, and ?2745.7 with respect to that accident within six months of the release or by the time the RMP is updated under ?2745.10, whichever is earlier.  19 CCR ?2750.9 states:

The owner or operator shall include in the five-year accident history all accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in

place, property damage, or environmental damage.



Sun-Maid Ripperdan - Facility has had no releases in the last five years that meets the five-year accident history reporting criteria. 



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Sun-Maid Ripperdan - Facility is a non-responding facility and does not train employees for active responses to sulfur dioxide releases.  This facility will rely upon the local emergency hazardous materials response team and the local Fire Department for responses to uncontrolled releases of sulfur dioxide.  In accordance with 19 CCR ?2765.1, the facility is not required to have an Emergency Response Plan in place.  However, it is required to have appropriate mechanisms in place for notifying emergency responders when there is a need for response.  These mechanisms are described below. 

 

The Facility submitted a Hazardous Material Inventory (HMI) Business Plan via California Environmental Reporting System (CERS) in November 27, 2019.  The Facility has procedures in place to evacuate the facility and notify responders when there is a need for a response.  A current copy of the Emergency Action Plan (EAP) can be found with the Safety Manager.





PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Several studies have been conducted to examine mitigation measures to improve safety at the facility.  These studies include the following: Hazard Review and Hazard Assessment, performed on July 8, 2020.  In addition, a Compliance Audit was performed on October 5, 2018.  

Any outstanding recommendations from these studies will have been addressed by January 2023



EXTERNAL EVENTS ASSESSMENT



Pursuant to the requirements of California Code of Regulations, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, Section ?2745.6 (l), general events external to the plant that can conceivably cause a release of sulfur dioxide were addressed by the July 8, 2020 for the sulfur dioxide covered process.  Specifically, the external events requirements were met with the following actions.

is installed and maintained as designed is August 1, 2019 and included: the entire sulfur process, as well as system valves, flexible hoses, piping inspections, tunnel maintenance, and door seals.

n of the types of natural and human caused external events considered in PHA 19 CCR ?2760.2 or Hazard Review 19 CCR ?2755.2.  

?During the July 8, 2020 PHA, a broad list of external events was considered by the PHA Team.  However, the Team only deemed some of these events as being credible, and fully developed those scenarios that present an opportunity for sulfur dioxide release.  



The estimated magnitude or scope of external events which were considered.  If not known, the owner or operator of the stationary source shall work closely with the AA to determine what is required. If seismic events are applicable, the parameters used in the consideration of the seismic analysis and which edition of the Uniform Building Code was used when the process was designed.

?The magnitude of the external events considered is detailed within the July 8, 2020 PHA Worksheets, within node 6.



For each external event, with a potential to create a release of a regulated substance that will reach an endpoint offsite, apply  

- The expected date of completion of any changes resulting from the PHA;

- Major hazards identified;

- Process controls in use;

- Mitigation systems in use;

- Monitoring and detection systems in use; and,

- Changes since the last PHA.

?Refer to Section 5.0 of this document, under PHA, for the required information.

?The recommendations precipitating from the July 8, 2020 are summarized in the "PHA" report, within Attachment B.  All recommendations are documented, with a date of a completion and description of the action required.

?The Human Factors were discussed in the July 8, 2020 PHA, as a separate node (refer to node 7 of the PHA Report).  The worksheets can be found in the 2020 PHA report, which also include; major hazards identified, process controls in use, mitigation systems in use, and monitoring and detection systems in use.
